response.summary: Applying the PSLRA’s heightened pleading standards, the Exchange Act §10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim is dismissed for failure to plead facts with particularity giving rise to a strong inference that any defendant knew challenged statements were false when made (or acted with deliberate recklessness). The complaint relies heavily on generalized “growth-at-all-costs” theory, later regulatory actions, and confidential-witness descriptions of operational problems, but it does not plead particularized, contemporaneous facts tying specific false statements to specific contrary information actually known to each speaker at the time. Because the §10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim is dismissed, the derivative §20(a) control-person claim is also dismissed. The §20(A) insider-trading claim is dismissed because it is pleaded as derivative of the alleged fraud and, in any event, does not plead with particularity the specific material nonpublic information possessed by each trading defendant at the time of each trade. The Securities Act claims (§§11, 12(a)(2), 15) are not subject to PSLRA scienter pleading, and the complaint plausibly alleges material omissions/misstatements in the 2022 offering documents concerning known, then-existing title/registration compliance problems and related regulatory actions; those claims are sustained at the pleading stage (subject to defendants’ due-diligence and negative-causation defenses on a developed record).

claim_rulings.claim: Count I – Exchange Act §10(b) and Rule 10b-5 (against Carvana, Garcia Senior, Garcia Junior, Jenkins, Keeton, Huston)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis:
1) Particularized knowledge of falsity: Not adequately pleaded. The complaint identifies many challenged statements (e.g., about scalable logistics, capital-light expansion, GPU, and title/registration issues) and alleges operational dysfunction and later regulatory sanctions. But it does not plead, for each specific statement, particularized contemporaneous facts showing the speaker actually knew the statement was false when made. The CW allegations largely describe lower-level observations (quality issues, missing titles, logistics inefficiencies) and generalized internal awareness (“everyone knew”), without identifying specific reports, dashboards, emails, meeting minutes, or metrics that were presented to (or reviewed by) the individual defendants at the time the challenged statements were made, and that directly contradicted those statements. For example: (a) statements about retail unit growth and sustainability are attacked as “unsustainable,” but unsustainability is largely inferred from later declines and later admissions—an impermissible hindsight theory absent contemporaneous contradictory facts; (b) the GPU “manipulation” theory is framed as a disagreement about cost classification (outbound logistics and title/registration in SG&A rather than cost of sales). The complaint does not plead particularized facts showing defendants believed the reported non-GAAP metric was false under the disclosed definition at the time, as opposed to plaintiffs’ view that it was misleading because it omitted other costs; and (c) as to title/registration, CWs describe pervasive delays and later state actions, but the complaint does not plead particularized facts that, when defendants made specific minimization statements (e.g., North Carolina being small/unusual; later progress statements), they possessed concrete data showing the contrary scope/illegality in a way that makes falsity obvious rather than debatable.

2) Strong inference of scienter: Not met. The more compelling inference from the pleaded facts is that Carvana pursued aggressive growth and struggled operationally (especially during COVID-era disruptions), with compliance and logistics problems that management attempted to address over time. The complaint’s scienter theory rests substantially on motive/opportunity (insider sales; desire to maintain valuation), generalized “core operations” reasoning, SOX certifications, and later regulatory findings. Under the PSLRA, those allegations—without particularized contemporaneous facts showing actual knowledge of falsity—do not yield a strong inference of intent to deceive that is at least as compelling as innocent explanations. Insider selling, including under 10b5-1 plans, may contribute to an inference, but here it does not bridge the gap where the complaint fails to plead what each defendant knew and when, and the sales are also consistent with diversification/liquidity in a high-volatility growth stock. The allegations therefore do not satisfy the PSLRA’s strong-inference requirement.

claim_rulings.claim: Count II – Exchange Act §20(a) control-person liability (against Exchange Act defendants)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Section 20(a) is derivative. Because the complaint fails to plead a primary violation under §10(b)/Rule 10b-5, the §20(a) claim is dismissed as a matter of law.

claim_rulings.claim: Count III – Exchange Act §20(A) insider trading (against Garcia Senior, Jenkins, Keeton, Huston)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Although §20(A) does not require pleading scienter as to misstatements in the same manner as §10(b), the claim still requires a predicate Exchange Act violation and particularized allegations that each defendant traded while in possession of specific material nonpublic information. The complaint alleges generally that defendants possessed MNPI about operational/logistics/title problems and that they sold stock, but it does not plead with particularity the precise MNPI each defendant had at the time of each trade, how and when they obtained it, and why it was material at that moment. The allegations largely track the broader fraud narrative and rely on later regulatory events and generalized internal awareness. With Count I dismissed, the §20(A) claim—pleaded as contemporaneous trading in connection with the alleged fraud—also fails on this record.

claim_rulings.claim: Count IV – Securities Act §11 (against Carvana, signing officers/directors, and underwriters) (2022 Public Offering)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Scienter is not an element and is expressly disclaimed. The complaint plausibly alleges that the offering documents incorporated the 2021 10-K and contained statements touting efficient logistics, scalable operations, high-quality inventory, and risk-factor language framing title/registration compliance issues largely as potential risks, while omitting then-existing, concrete compliance failures and regulatory actions (including, as alleged, Michigan’s probation/fines and broader, ongoing title/registration breakdowns) that could render those statements misleading. At the pleading stage, plaintiffs plausibly allege materiality and a misleading omission theory tied to the time of the offering. Defendants’ due-diligence and negative-causation defenses are not resolved on a motion to dismiss.

claim_rulings.claim: Count V – Securities Act §12(a)(2) (against Securities Act defendants)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Scienter is not required and is disclaimed. Plaintiffs plausibly allege that shares were sold by means of a prospectus containing materially misleading statements/omissions concerning then-existing title/registration compliance problems and operational constraints. Plaintiffs also plead purchases in the offering from an underwriter. To the extent certain defendants dispute statutory-seller/solicitation status, that is not conclusively resolved from the pleadings as presented here.

claim_rulings.claim: Count VI – Securities Act §15 control-person liability (against Individual Securities Act defendants)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Because Counts IV and V are adequately pleaded at this stage, and the complaint plausibly alleges control through officer/director status and participation in the offering and signing of the registration statement, the §15 claim is sustained (subject to proof and any statutory defenses).

response.summary: Applying the PSLRA’s heightened pleading standards, the Complaint adequately pleads a Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim against Musk (and, through corporate scienter/agency principles, Tesla) based on particularized allegations that Musk knew—at the time of his August 7 and August 13 statements—that “funding secured,” “investor support is confirmed,” and related assertions conveyed a level of commitment and deal certainty that did not exist. The pleading ties falsity and contemporaneous knowledge to specific events (the July 31 PIF meeting; the absence of any discussion of $420 with funders; Musk’s own contemporaneous assessment of only ~50% likelihood; lack of term sheet/commitment/advisors; internal texts/emails reflecting surprise; and Musk’s later admissions/SEC allegations he agreed not to deny). These facts support a strong inference of at least deliberate recklessness, and the competing innocent inference (optimistic but good-faith belief that PIF interest equaled secured funding) is less compelling given the pleaded absence of any price/structure agreement and Musk’s alleged recognition of substantial uncertainty. The Section 20(a) claim against the Board is insufficiently pleaded because it rests on generalized assertions of board-level oversight and post hoc ability to influence communications, without particularized facts showing each director’s actual control over the specific alleged misstatements or culpable participation; moreover, the Complaint does not plead with particularity that the Board members themselves knew of the falsity at the time or exercised actual control over Musk’s tweets when made. Accordingly, Count I is sustained; Count II is dismissed.

claim_rulings.claim: Count I – Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5 (against Musk and Tesla)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis:
1) Particularized knowledge of falsity: The Complaint pleads specific, time-linked facts showing Musk knew (or was deliberately reckless in not knowing) that his statements conveyed secured financing and near-certainty when that was not true. It alleges: (i) the July 31 meeting with the PIF was brief and preliminary, with no term sheet, no signed documents, and no discussion of key terms (including price, structure, amount, ownership, regulatory issues); (ii) Musk chose $420 unilaterally on Aug. 2 based on a premium and a joke, and did not discuss $420 with PIF or any financier before tweeting; (iii) Musk contemporaneously believed there was “a lot of uncertainty” and only ~50% likelihood of consummation; (iv) he had not retained advisors or obtained board approval for a formal proposal at the time; (v) contemporaneous internal/external reactions (IR director texting “Was this text legit?”; analysts asking about funding details; IR responses reflecting lack of knowledge) support the inference the tweet was not grounded in an actual commitment; and (vi) the pleading relies on Musk’s later admissions/SEC-alleged facts he agreed not to deny, including that the statements were “premised on a long series of baseless assumptions” and contrary to facts he knew. These are not merely “knew or should have known” allegations; they identify what Musk knew (no agreed terms/commitment; no $420 discussion; substantial contingencies) when he spoke.

2) Strong inference vs. innocent explanations: Considering the allegations holistically, the inference that Musk acted with intent or deliberate recklessness is at least as compelling as any nonfraudulent inference. The pleaded facts show Musk publicly stated “funding secured” and “only reason this is not certain is … shareholder vote” despite recognizing major unresolved contingencies and lacking any commitment at the stated price. An innocent inference (Musk genuinely believed PIF enthusiasm equaled secured funding) is weakened by the pleaded absence of any price discussion, the acknowledged uncertainty, and the magnitude/definitiveness of the public claims. At the pleading stage, these particularized allegations satisfy the PSLRA’s strong-inference requirement as to Musk. As to Tesla, the Complaint pleads corporate liability based on Musk acting as CEO/spokesperson through an identified official channel of communication and alleges Tesla investor relations reiterated the “funding secured” assertion; at minimum, Musk’s pleaded scienter is adequately attributed to Tesla for purposes of the motion to dismiss.

claim_rulings.claim: Count II – Section 20(a) (against the Board)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Section 20(a) requires (among other elements) control over the primary violator and, in this Circuit, culpable participation. The Complaint pleads control largely by status (director roles; generalized oversight duties; Tesla’s 2013 identification of Musk’s Twitter as a channel) and cites post-tweet actions (press release; directing Musk not to tweet during part of the period). Those allegations do not plead, with particularity, that each director had actual power to control Musk’s specific tweets at the time they were made, or that any director knew the tweets were false when made, approved them, or participated in their dissemination. The allegations amount to generalized corporate governance and “should have overseen” theories, which are insufficient under the PSLRA. Because the Complaint does not plead particularized facts establishing each Board defendant’s control and culpable participation in the alleged fraud, Count II is dismissed.

response.summary: Applying the PSLRA’s heightened pleading standards, the complaint identifies allegedly misleading statements about Netflix’s market penetration, subscriber growth headroom, and the causes of slowing acquisition, and it plausibly alleges that Netflix internally tracked account-sharing. But it does not plead with the required particularity facts showing that any Individual Defendant actually knew, at the time of the challenged statements, that specific quantitative account-sharing levels (e.g., “over 100m” global / “over 30m” UCAN) rendered contemporaneous statements false, or that they deliberately or recklessly misrepresented those facts. The former-employee allegations are not tied to dates, speakers, specific reports, or what any defendant saw before making the challenged statements; they largely support that Netflix monitored account sharing generally (which Netflix publicly acknowledged), not that defendants knew their specific penetration statements were false when made. The competing, nonfraudulent inference—that Netflix treated account sharing as a known but hard-to-quantify industry-wide issue, disclosed it as a risk factor, and later refined/quantified estimates and strategy as growth slowed—is at least as compelling as an inference of intent to deceive. Accordingly, the Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim is dismissed for failure to plead a strong inference of scienter, and the derivative Section 20(a) claim is also dismissed.

claim_rulings.claim: Section 10(b) of the Exchange Act and Rule 10b-5 (against all defendants)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis:
1) Particularized knowledge of falsity: Not adequately pleaded. The complaint relies on (i) Netflix’s April 2022 disclosure of quantified sharing (“over 100m”/“over 30m”) and the assertion that sharing ‘hasn’t changed much over the years,’ (ii) generalized allegations that executives had access to internal data by virtue of their roles, and (iii) two former employees’ statements that password sharing was discussed and that Netflix could track IP addresses. These allegations do not identify, with particularity, any contemporaneous internal report, dashboard, memo, or meeting material that quantified account-sharing households (or UCAN penetration) during the class period, when it was generated, who received it, and that any specific Individual Defendant reviewed it before making the challenged statements (e.g., Neumann’s ‘roughly 60% penetrated’ UCAN remarks; ‘no structural change’ comments). FE2’s account of quarterly reviews is not anchored to dates, does not describe the specific metrics shown, and does not connect the content of any presentation to the precise allegedly false public statements. FE1’s memo allegation concerns pausing a crackdown during COVID for reputational reasons; it does not plead that the memo contained the later-disclosed quantitative figures or that any defendant read it. The complaint’s penetration calculations are plaintiffs’ reconstructions from later disclosures, which is insufficient under the PSLRA to plead that defendants knew the earlier statements were false when made.

2) Strong inference of scienter: Not adequately pleaded. The more compelling inference is nonfraudulent: Netflix publicly acknowledged account sharing for years, disclosed it as a risk factor (including that abuse could hinder growth), and later—amid slowing growth and an evolving monetization strategy—publicly quantified its estimate and reframed its narrative. The complaint’s theory largely amounts to ‘they must have known’ because Netflix could monitor sharing and later disclosed estimates; that is the kind of speculation and hindsight pleading the PSLRA forbids. Allegations of testing paid-sharing features and monitoring account sharing support awareness of the issue, not intent to deceive about specific penetration levels. Absent particularized facts tying quantified internal knowledge to the speakers and the timing of the challenged statements, the allegations do not yield a strong inference that defendants acted with intent to deceive or deliberate recklessness, as opposed to making optimistic/interpretive statements about growth drivers while lacking (or not treating as sufficiently reliable) a precise, reportable estimate until later.

claim_rulings.claim: Section 20(a) control person liability (against the Individual Defendants)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Section 20(a) is derivative and requires a primary violation. Because the Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim is dismissed for failure to plead scienter under the PSLRA, the Section 20(a) claim is also dismissed.

response.summary: Applying the PSLRA’s heightened pleading standards, the complaint pleads with particularity numerous contemporaneous facts—primarily from identified former employees—supporting that Rawlinson (and, to a lesser extent, House) knew Lucid’s production guidance and related explanations were misleading when made. The allegations are not merely hindsight: they describe specific internal meetings, reports, plant/warehouse visits, and emails occurring before and during the challenged statements, including an alleged October/early November 2021 admission by Rawlinson that 2022 production would be under 10,000 and instructions to keep that information confidential. Those allegations, taken collectively, support a strong inference of at least deliberate recklessness (and plausibly actual knowledge) as to the falsity/misleading nature of the guidance and the repeated attribution of production constraints primarily to generalized industry supply-chain issues. At the pleading stage, innocent explanations (optimism, execution risk, evolving forecasts) are less compelling than the inference that defendants publicly maintained aggressive guidance and an externalized causal narrative despite internally recognizing materially lower achievable production and severe company-specific logistics bottlenecks. Accordingly, Count I is sustained. Because an underlying Exchange Act violation is adequately pleaded, the derivative Section 20(a) claim is also sustained.

claim_rulings.claim: Count I – Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5 (against Lucid, Rawlinson, House)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis:
1) Particularized knowledge-of-falsity allegations: As to Rawlinson, the complaint pleads specific, time-bounded facts that he knew the production guidance was unattainable when publicly reaffirmed. Most notably, FE-2 alleges Rawlinson stated in an October 2021 or first-week-of-November 2021 meeting that Lucid would produce fewer than 10,000 vehicles in 2022 and instructed attendees to keep that information confidential (¶¶ 15, 289). The complaint also pleads repeated direct communications to Rawlinson from FE-1 in September and November 2021 that warehouse/logistics dysfunction made the targets impossible, coupled with Rawlinson’s frequent in-person visits to the warehouse/plant where the alleged conditions were visible (¶¶ 219-227, 285-286). In addition, the complaint pleads Rawlinson’s access to (and/or receipt of) recurring internal reports and meetings describing inventory-system failures, hot calls, line stoppages, and logistics bottlenecks (e.g., Daily AM/PM reports; end-of-shift meetings; ¶¶ 228-229). As to House, the complaint pleads fewer direct knowledge facts, but includes a July 2021 inventory meeting attended by House where inventory-control accuracy was discussed (¶ 168) and allegations that House received/was copied on emails seeking approval to scrap tens of millions of dollars of inventory to ‘start fresh’ (¶¶ 211-213), supporting awareness of severe internal logistics dysfunction while the company continued to attribute constraints largely to generalized industry supply-chain issues.

2) Strong inference of scienter vs. innocent explanations: Considering the allegations holistically, the inference that Rawlinson acted with at least deliberate recklessness is strong. The complaint alleges contemporaneous internal recognition of materially lower achievable production (<10,000) while Rawlinson publicly reaffirmed 20,000 (Nov. 15–16, 2021) and later 12,000–14,000 (Feb. 28, May 5, May 20–26, 2022), repeatedly framing the principal constraints as industrywide supply-chain/logistics issues being mitigated. The alleged instruction to keep the <10,000 figure confidential materially strengthens scienter and distinguishes the pleading from ‘fraud by hindsight.’ The pleaded facts also support that defendants’ repeated causal narrative (external supply-chain constraints) omitted known, severe, company-specific logistics breakdowns that were already causing frequent shutdowns and inability to move parts to the line. While defendants may argue nonfraudulent explanations (good-faith forecasting, rapidly changing conditions, prioritizing quality, pandemic disruption), those explanations are less plausible at this stage given the alleged internal admission of a sub-10,000 outcome months earlier and the detailed allegations of persistent, structural logistics failures known to senior leadership. The complaint therefore meets the PSLRA requirement to plead facts giving rise to a strong inference of scienter.

claim_rulings.claim: Count II – Section 20(a) control person liability (against Rawlinson, House)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Section 20(a) is derivative. Because the complaint adequately pleads a primary violation under Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 at this stage, the control-person claim is not subject to dismissal on the ground that no underlying violation exists. The complaint also pleads control through senior executive roles and alleged involvement in, and authority over, the challenged statements (¶¶ 41-45, 530-532).

response.summary: Applying the PSLRA’s heightened pleading standards, the complaint adequately pleads falsity/materiality as to certain statements (particularly the later-filed 2023 quarterly financials that were restated, and some concrete “no customer stopped using AviClear”/“successful launch” type assertions). But the Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim fails because the complaint does not plead with particularity facts giving rise to a strong inference that each defendant knew the challenged statements were false when made (or was deliberately reckless). Most scienter allegations rely on generalized “must have known” theories, core-operations inferences, post hoc restatement/operational failure, and CW accounts that are not tied with specificity to what each Individual Defendant actually received, when, and how it contradicted the specific public statements at issue. Innocent explanations—botched ERP implementation, fast growth/rollout pains, poor execution, and later-discovered accounting/process errors—are at least as plausible as an intent to deceive. Because the Section 10(b) claim is dismissed, the derivative Section 20(a) control-person claim is also dismissed.

claim_rulings.claim: First Claim for Relief — Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5(b) (against Cutera and all Individual Defendants)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis:
1) Particularized knowledge of falsity at the time: The complaint alleges numerous operational problems (inventory control failures, ERP/Salesforce implementation issues, product reliability, returns) and later corrective disclosures/restatements. It also pleads CW statements that certain issues were discussed internally and that Mowry received complaints. However, the pleading largely does not connect, with the required particularity, the content of contemporaneous internal reports/metrics to the specific public statements and to each defendant at the time each statement was made. For example, allegations that (a) ‘everyone knew AviClear was struggling,’ (b) issues were ‘raised in meetings,’ (c) it was ‘impossible’ for executives not to know, or (d) executives worked in the same building as inventory, are not the same as pleading specific contradictory facts actually known to each speaker when speaking. The complaint does not plead particularized facts that Plants, Seth, Hopkins, Harris, Drummond, or Varma actually reviewed concrete internal data showing falsity of the precise challenged statements at the time (e.g., specific utilization/return-rate dashboards, specific inventory reconciliation reports, specific auditor warnings, or specific communications showing awareness that reported inventory/cost of revenue figures were wrong when filed). As to the SOX certifications, a restatement and later-admitted control weaknesses do not, without more, establish that the certifying officers knew the financials were false when certified.

2) Strong inference of scienter vs. innocent explanations: The more compelling inference from the pleaded facts is mismanagement/poor execution and later-discovered accounting and process failures during an ERP transition and an aggressive product rollout, rather than intent to deceive. The complaint’s scienter theory depends heavily on (i) the existence of later restatements and disclosed material weaknesses (which can reflect error, not fraud), (ii) generalized core-operations reasoning, (iii) compensation incentives tied to placements (motive allegations that are common to executives and not, standing alone, sufficient), and (iv) executive departures/terminations (which may reflect governance disputes or performance issues rather than contemporaneous knowledge of falsity). These allegations do not yield a strong inference that is at least as compelling as nonfraudulent inferences. Accordingly, scienter is not pleaded with the PSLRA-required particularity, and the Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim is dismissed.

claim_rulings.claim: Second Claim for Relief — Section 20(a) (against the Individual Defendants)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Section 20(a) liability is derivative and requires a primary violation of the Exchange Act. Because the Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim is dismissed for failure to plead scienter under the PSLRA, the Section 20(a) claim is also dismissed.

response.summary: Applying the PSLRA’s heightened pleading standards, the Court DISMISSES the Exchange Act claims (Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 and derivative Section 20(a)) because the complaint does not plead with particularity facts giving rise to a strong inference that Vellanki or Bryce actually knew the challenged statements were false when made (or were deliberately reckless). The scienter allegations largely rest on (i) disagreement with the wisdom of a Phase 2 bypass, (ii) generalized assertions of what executives “must have known,” (iii) post hoc inference from the MANTRA failure and later analyst commentary, and (iv) an ex-employee’s conclusory statements lacking the specific detail the PSLRA requires. By contrast, the Securities Act claims under Sections 11 and 15 are not subject to PSLRA scienter pleading, and the complaint adequately pleads actionable misstatements/omissions in the IPO registration statement/prospectus regarding (a) whether Phase 1 data ‘validated’ dosing and mitigated safety concerns and (b) risk-factor disclosure about the atypical Phase 2 bypass. Those claims are therefore SUSTAINED at the pleading stage.

claim_rulings.claim: Count I – Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5 (against Rain, Vellanki, and Bryce)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis:
1) Knowledge of falsity when made (particularized facts): Not adequately pleaded. The core alleged falsity is that defendants stated Phase 1 data ‘validated’ a dosing schedule, ‘mitigate[d] safety concerns,’ and supported moving to a pivotal Phase 3 trial without Phase 2. The complaint pleads, at most, that Phase 2 bypass was aggressive and contrary to customary practice, and that Daiichi Sankyo’s protocol contemplated a Phase 2 dose and potential Phase 2 follow-on. That is not the same as pleading that defendants knew their statements were false at the time—i.e., that they did not believe the Phase 1 results supported the chosen schedule or Phase 3 initiation, or that they knew the statements were objectively untrue rather than debatable scientific judgments.

The SEC-comment correspondence is not a particularized admission of falsity of the later challenged statements. The SEC letters (as quoted) primarily concern (a) characterizing Rain as ‘late-stage,’ (b) pipeline-table presentation implying progress, and (c) avoiding ‘best-in-class’/‘first-in-class’ inferences. They do not specifically state that Rain could not reasonably describe Phase 1 data as supporting Phase 3 initiation, nor do they show that Vellanki/Bryce knew such statements were false. Re-using ‘late-stage’ language after the SEC comments may support negligence or poor compliance, but the PSLRA requires particularized facts of intent to deceive or deliberate recklessness as to falsity.

The former employee allegations (FE1) are also insufficiently particularized. FE1 offers generalized opinions that Phase 2 is usually needed to ‘dial in’ dosing and that Phase 1 recommended a ‘Phase 2 dose.’ FE1 then asserts Vellanki and Bryce ‘were aware’ of limitations and ‘understood’ the Phase 1 data. But the complaint does not plead the required detail: what specific internal documents, meetings, emails, or contemporaneous statements show that either individual believed the public statements were false; when and how FE1 conveyed contrary information; what exactly was said; and how that contradicts the challenged statements. Under the PSLRA, such conclusory ‘they knew’ assertions and generalized corporate-knowledge allegations do not suffice.

2) Strong inference of scienter: Not adequately pleaded; innocent explanations are at least as plausible. The more compelling inference from the pleaded facts is that defendants made optimistic characterizations of early clinical data and pursued an aggressive development strategy typical of clinical-stage biotech companies seeking speed-to-market and capital efficiency—conduct that may be risky or even imprudent, but is not inherently fraudulent. The later MANTRA failure and analyst commentary that dosing ‘was too high’ are classic ‘fraud by hindsight’ allegations and do not establish that defendants knew, at the time of the challenged statements, that Phase 3 would fail or that the dosing schedule was not supportable. The complaint’s motive allegations (need to fundraise, desire to save time/money, first-to-market) are generalized and common to virtually all issuers; they do not create a strong inference of scienter absent particularized facts tying motive to knowing falsity.

Accordingly, Count I is dismissed for failure to plead scienter with particularity and to allege facts supporting a strong inference of scienter.

claim_rulings.claim: Count II – Section 20(a) control person liability (against Vellanki and Bryce)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Section 20(a) is derivative. Because the Court dismisses the underlying Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim in Count I, Count II must also be dismissed.

claim_rulings.claim: Count III – Section 11 (against Rain and Director Defendants)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Scienter is not an element of Section 11, and plaintiffs expressly plead this count on a non-fraud basis. At the pleading stage, the complaint plausibly alleges material misstatements/omissions in the IPO registration statement/prospectus, including statements that the Phase 1 trial ‘validated’ a dosing schedule ‘shown to mitigate safety concerns’ and that, ‘[b]ased on these data,’ Rain anticipated commencing a pivotal Phase 3 trial—along with alleged omissions regarding the atypical nature and specific risks of bypassing Phase 2 (Item 105 risk-factor theory). Plaintiffs also plead traceability to the offering. These allegations are sufficient to proceed under Section 11 at this stage, subject to defendants’ potential affirmative defenses (e.g., negative causation) not resolvable on the pleadings here.

claim_rulings.claim: Count IV – Section 15 control person liability (against Director Defendants)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Section 15 is derivative of a primary Securities Act violation. Because Count III (Section 11) is adequately pleaded at this stage, the Section 15 claim may proceed as well, based on the Director Defendants’ alleged control and their roles in signing/authorizing the registration statement.

response.summary: COUNT I (Exchange Act §10(b)/Rule 10b-5) is dismissed for failure to plead scienter with the PSLRA-required particularity. Although the complaint pleads nonpublic facts suggesting Fastly faced pricing pressure and traffic declines among large customers, it does not plead particularized facts showing that Nightingale or Kisling actually knew specific challenged public statements were false when made, as opposed to making arguably optimistic or incomplete characterizations amid a volatile, usage-based, multi-CDN customer environment. The more compelling inference from the pleaded facts is mismanagement/over-optimism and later-emerging adverse customer dynamics (including late-March/early-April rerates), not an intent to deceive. Because the §10(b) claim is dismissed, COUNT II (§20(a)) is also dismissed as derivative.

claim_rulings.claim: Count I — Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5 (against all Defendants)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis:
PSLRA requires particularized facts giving rise to a strong inference that each defendant acted with intent to deceive or deliberate recklessness at the time of each challenged statement. The complaint relies heavily on (a) confidential witnesses describing discount requests, churn, and internal discussions; (b) generalized allegations that the C-suite ‘knew’ because of all-hands meetings, internal tools, and weekly customer-ops meetings; (c) later disclosures in May/August 2024; and (d) insider sales and discontinuation of certain metrics.

(1) Knowledge of falsity when made. The complaint does not plead with particularity that Nightingale or Kisling had contemporaneous, statement-specific knowledge contradicting what they said publicly. The all-hands allegations (Nov. 2023 discussion of ‘big customers’ throttling down) support that management knew of some traffic softness, but they do not plead the magnitude, duration, or financial impact necessary to show that statements like ‘we’re not seeing’ macro headwinds, ‘customer retention efforts were stable,’ or guidance assumptions about ‘continued expansion’ were knowingly false as stated, rather than debatable characterizations in a business where usage and traffic fluctuate and where retention/expansion metrics can remain positive despite pockets of weakness.

Critically, the May 1, 2024 disclosures attribute the most acute guidance reset to dynamics that ‘arose really at the end of March and in early April’ (larger-than-expected rerate discounts without commensurate traffic expansion and reversal of consolidation). That timing undercuts an inference that, in November 2023 or February 2024, defendants necessarily knew the later-described rerate/traffic combination would materialize to the extent it did. Allegations that contract negotiations typically begin three months before renewal and thus defendants ‘should have known’ by January 2024 are precisely the kind of ‘knew or should have known’ and speculative corporate-knowledge pleading the PSLRA does not permit.

The CW allegations about cancellations (Indeed, USAA) and discount requests show sales headwinds, but they do not connect to what Nightingale or Kisling actually reviewed, when, and how that information rendered the specific public statements false. Nor do the CWs identify specific reports, dashboards, emails, board materials, or meeting minutes reviewed by Nightingale/Kisling that quantified enterprise retention deterioration or established that ‘retention efforts were stable’ was false at the time. Assertions that ‘anyone’ could see traffic in an internal app, or that executives ‘occasionally’ attended weekly meetings, do not plead that these defendants actually saw data contradicting their public statements.

(2) Strong inference of scienter vs. innocent explanations. Considering the allegations holistically, the competing nonfraudulent inferences are at least as compelling as fraudulent intent: (i) management optimism and/or imprecise public messaging about macro conditions and customer behavior; (ii) volatility and forecasting difficulty inherent in usage-based revenue and multi-CDN traffic allocation; (iii) a good-faith belief that engagement-model changes could stabilize large accounts; and (iv) a later-emerging, sharper-than-expected rerate/traffic dynamic crystallizing in late March/early April 2024.

The additional scienter indicators do not tip the balance. Insider sales are pleaded in gross share/proceeds terms without the context typically required to infer scienter (e.g., percentage of holdings sold, trading history, 10b5-1 plans, timing relative to specific statements). Discontinuation of DBNER/quarterly NRR is not, without more, a particularized fact showing intent to conceal fraud; companies may change metrics for multiple reasons, and the complaint does not plead internal communications showing the change was adopted to hide known falsity. The complaint’s repeated reliance on ‘known throughout the Company’ and ‘C-suite absolutely knew’ is generalized corporate knowledge, not the individualized, contemporaneous facts required.

Accordingly, plaintiffs fail to plead facts giving rise to a strong inference that Nightingale or Kisling acted with intent to deceive or deliberate recklessness. Count I is dismissed.

particularized_knowledge_findings.explanation: The complaint does not plead contemporaneous, defendant-specific facts (e.g., identified internal reports reviewed by Nightingale/Kisling, quantified contrary metrics, specific dates and contents of communications to them) showing they actually knew the challenged public statements were false at the time. Allegations rely on CW opinions, generalized access to information, and hindsight from later disclosures.

strong_inference_findings.explanation: Innocent inferences—forecasting difficulty and volatility in usage-based multi-CDN traffic, management optimism, and late-March/early-April rerate dynamics—are at least as plausible as fraudulent intent. The pleaded insider sales and metric changes lack the contextual detail needed to support a strong inference.

claim_rulings.claim: Count II — Section 20(a) control person liability (against Nightingale and Kisling)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Section 20(a) is derivative and requires a primary violation. Because Count I (§10(b)/Rule 10b-5) is dismissed for failure to plead scienter under the PSLRA, Count II is dismissed as well.

response.summary: Applying the PSLRA’s heightened pleading standards, Count One fails because the complaint does not plead with particularity facts showing that, when the July 25, 2023 statements were made, either defendant actually knew the statements were false (or was deliberately reckless). The scienter allegations rely primarily on (i) later disappointment/changed messaging in October 2023, (ii) the magnitude of the stock move, (iii) generalized assertions of “access” to information and “must have known,” and (iv) motive allegations based on stock ownership and some insider sales by unspecified persons. Those allegations amount to speculation and fraud-by-hindsight and do not create a strong inference of scienter that is at least as compelling as innocent explanations (e.g., a customer program timing changed; bookings/allocations were understood to exist but later shifted; management chose not to discuss customer specifics). Because the Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim is dismissed, the derivative Section 20(a) control-person claim is also dismissed.

claim_rulings.claim: Count One — Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5(b) (misstatements/omissions) against Vicor and Vinciarelli
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis:
1) Particularized knowledge of falsity: Not adequately pleaded. The complaint quotes the July 25 call and alleges the ‘announcement was false’ because Vicor later did not discuss the customer and later ‘pivoted.’ But it pleads no contemporaneous internal facts (e.g., specific contract terms, emails, board materials, CRM entries, forecasts, customer communications, or witness accounts) showing that, on July 25, 2023, defendants knew there was no “existing” “significant” customer program ramping in Q4 or knew their characterization was false. Allegations that management had ‘unlimited access’ to contracts and customer lists (¶¶ 88–89, 103–106) are generic corporate-knowledge assertions and do not satisfy the PSLRA’s requirement to plead with particularity what each defendant knew and when.

2) Strong inference of scienter: Not adequately pleaded. Plaintiffs’ theory is largely that because the October 24 call sounded different, the July 25 statements must have been knowingly false. That is classic fraud by hindsight. The more compelling non-fraud inferences are at least as plausible: customer demand, allocations, qualification timelines, or deployment plans can change; management may have been referring to expected ramp based on then-current customer inputs; and later reluctance to discuss ‘any one customer’ may reflect confidentiality or changed business circumstances rather than consciousness of guilt. Motive allegations are also insufficient: Vinciarelli’s large equity stake and options (¶¶ 97–99) describe a common executive incentive to see stock price rise, not particularized fraudulent intent. The complaint also alleges ‘certain Vicor insiders’ sold ‘well over $1 million’ (¶ 100) but does not identify who sold, whether Vinciarelli sold, whether sales were unusual in timing/amount, or how they support an inference that the July 25 statements were known false when made. The allegation that an 8-K ‘naturally would have’ been filed (¶¶ 67–68) is speculative and does not plead actual knowledge of falsity.

Accordingly, plaintiffs do not plead facts giving rise to a strong inference of scienter that is at least as compelling as innocent explanations.

claim_rulings.claim: Count Two — Section 20(a) control person liability against Vinciarelli
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Section 20(a) is derivative and requires a primary violation. Because Count One (Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5) is dismissed for failure to plead scienter with particularity under the PSLRA, Count Two necessarily fails and is dismissed.

response.summary: Applying the PSLRA’s heightened pleading standards, the complaint does not plead with particularity facts giving rise to a strong inference that Faricy or Sial knew (or were deliberately reckless in not knowing) that the challenged statements were false when made. The scienter allegations are largely conclusory (e.g., “knew or deliberately disregarded”), rely on generalized “access to information” theories, and lean heavily on post hoc analyst speculation that the issue “must have” surfaced during CIS-sale due diligence—an inadequate basis for scienter. While the January 20, 2022 disclosure plausibly supports that a connector cracking issue existed and ultimately required charges, the complaint does not plead specific contemporaneous facts (internal reports, emails, meeting dates, whistleblower accounts, customer complaints tied to time periods, audit findings, or particularized allegations about what each Individual Defendant learned and when) showing actual knowledge during August–November 2021. Innocent explanations—e.g., the issue was identified later through a product quality assessment and/or emerged over time, with scope/cost crystallizing late 2021—are at least as plausible as fraudulent intent. Accordingly, Count I (§10(b)/Rule 10b-5) is dismissed. Because §20(a) is derivative, Count II is also dismissed.

claim_rulings.claim: Count I – Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5 (against all Defendants)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis:
1) Particularized knowledge of falsity: Not adequately pleaded. The complaint asserts that “nearly all” commercial systems already had cracking defects and that Defendants therefore misled investors by speaking of commercial strength, margins, guidance, and framing defect risk as hypothetical. But it does not plead particularized, contemporaneous facts showing that Faricy or Sial actually knew of the connector cracking issue (its pervasiveness, financial impact, or guidance implications) at the time of the August 3/4, October 5, or November 3/4 statements. There are no identified internal documents, specific meetings, dates of escalation, quality dashboards, field failure rates, customer incident reports, supplier notices, or witness accounts tying knowledge to either Individual Defendant during the relevant periods. The December 7, 2021 manual update suggests awareness by that date, but does not, without more, establish knowledge months earlier when the challenged statements were made.

2) Strong inference of scienter: Not met. Plaintiffs’ core scienter theory is that Defendants “must have” known because (a) the problem allegedly affected “nearly all” systems and would cost tens of millions, and (b) analysts speculated it likely surfaced in CIS sale due diligence. Those allegations amount to speculation and corporate-knowledge pleading, not the PSLRA-required particularized facts about each defendant’s state of mind. The competing, nonfraudulent inference—consistent with the January 20 press release—that the cracking issue developed over time and was identified through a product quality assessment, with scope and remediation costs becoming clear later in 2021, and/or emerging during diligence without showing earlier knowledge—is at least as plausible as an inference of intent to deceive or deliberate recklessness. The complaint therefore fails to plead scienter with the required strength, requiring dismissal of the §10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim.

claim_rulings.claim: Count II – Section 20(a) control person liability (against Individual Defendants)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Section 20(a) is derivative and requires a primary violation. Because Count I (§10(b)/Rule 10b-5) is dismissed for failure to plead scienter (and thus a primary violation), Count II is also dismissed.

response.summary: Applying the PSLRA’s heightened pleading standards, the Complaint alleges extensive cGMP deficiencies at a third-party CMO (AGC) and later FDA Form 483 observations culminating in a May 2023 CRL. The pleading is strongest on falsity/materiality (statements touting “GMP manufacturing capacity” and “cGMP-compliant” third-party facilities versus alleged known, ongoing, significant cGMP lapses and FDA observations). The dispositive issue is scienter. Although the Complaint offers confidential-witness accounts of frequent senior-level meetings with AGC, a mock inspection shortly before the FDA inspection, real-time updates during the FDA inspection, and alleged executive anxiety, it does not plead with the required particularity facts showing that each Individual Defendant (and the Company through them) actually knew that the specific challenged public statements were false when made, as opposed to knowing of manufacturing challenges, delays, and remediation efforts. The more compelling, nonfraudulent inference is that Defendants believed AGC’s issues were being managed/remediated and that their statements about having GMP capacity (largely framed around ImmunityBio’s own facilities/capabilities and generalized descriptions) were not understood internally as representations that AGC was then in full cGMP compliance or that approval was assured. The Complaint also risks impermissible “fraud by hindsight” by inferring contemporaneous knowledge of falsity from the later CRL/Form 483 results without tying that knowledge to the timing of each statement with defendant-specific facts. Accordingly, Count I is dismissed for failure to plead a strong inference of scienter with particularity. Because Section 20(a) is derivative, Count II is also dismissed.

claim_rulings.claim: Count I — Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5 (against all Defendants)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis:
PSLRA/Scienter prong (1): Particularized allegations of contemporaneous knowledge of falsity. The Complaint pleads that AGC had serious cGMP problems (Form 483s in March/July 2021; missed batch disposition timelines; delayed/open deviations; missed stability windows; reference material shortages; failed PPQ runs) and that ImmunityBio received information through a quality agreement and held frequent meetings with AGC. It further pleads a January 2023 mock inspection with results presented to Adcock/Sender, and real-time daily calls during the February 2023 FDA inspection, including that Soon‑Shiong demanded updates and Adcock traveled to the site. These allegations support that ImmunityBio leadership was aware of operational/manufacturing difficulties and heightened regulatory risk. But the Complaint does not plead with the required particularity that each Individual Defendant knew, at the time of each challenged statement, that the specific representations at issue were false—e.g., that statements touting ‘GMP manufacturing capacity at scale’ or describing the Anktiva manufacturer as having ‘multiple cGMP-compliant facilities’ were understood internally as false descriptions of AGC’s compliance status at the Bothell facility at the relevant times. The CW allegations are largely generalized (e.g., ‘leadership reviewed,’ ‘common knowledge,’ ‘very concerned’) and do not identify specific documents, emails, board materials, or contemporaneous reports provided to Adcock, Sachs, or Soon‑Shiong that directly contradicted the public statements when made. Nor does the pleading tie Sachs (in particular) to receipt of specific adverse cGMP information beyond his role signing filings and generalized assertions that costs ‘would have required’ his approval.

PSLRA/Scienter prong (2): Strong inference vs. equally plausible innocent inference. Considering the allegations holistically, the inference of scienter is not ‘cogent and at least as compelling’ as nonculpable explanations. A more plausible innocent inference is that Defendants knew AGC had compliance and timing issues typical of complex biologics manufacturing, believed remediation and ongoing oversight were underway, and continued to describe ImmunityBio’s overall manufacturing strategy/capabilities (often focused on its own GMP resources) while disclosing generally that CMOs may fail inspections and that there was ‘no guarantee’ of passing pre-approval inspections. Even after the February 2023 inspection, the Complaint does not plead particularized facts that Defendants actually knew the inspection outcome would necessarily preclude approval (as opposed to posing material risk) at the time they stated approval was ‘unclear’ or that they were preparing for ‘potential’ approval. The Complaint’s reliance on the later CRL and the severity of the Form 483/OAI classification to infer earlier intent risks impermissible fraud-by-hindsight. Because the Complaint does not plead defendant-specific, contemporaneous facts giving rise to a strong inference of intentional or deliberately reckless deception, Count I is dismissed.

claim_rulings.claim: Count II — Section 20(a) control person liability (against Individual Defendants)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Section 20(a) liability is derivative and requires a primary violation of the Exchange Act. Because Count I (Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5) is dismissed for failure to plead scienter under the PSLRA, Count II is also dismissed.

response.summary: Applying the PSLRA’s heightened pleading standards, the Court finds that the complaint pleads a plausible, particularized theory that the challenged statements were misleading as to the existence, scope, and financial/operational consequences of the powdered-metal contamination affecting Pratt & Whitney GTF engines. On scienter, however, the pleading is uneven by defendant. As to RTX and Hayes, the complaint alleges with particularity facts supporting actual knowledge by no later than 2020 (Hayes’s own later admissions tying the issue to the March 2020 V2500 incident and acknowledging a known suspect population, plus allegations of internal remediation efforts extending through 2021). Those allegations support a strong inference that Hayes (and thus RTX) acted at least recklessly in making/approving contrary public assurances during the Class Period. By contrast, as to Mitchill, O’Brien, Calio, and Eddy, the complaint largely relies on position, generalized “core operations” assertions, and lower-level former employee accounts not tied to what these individuals actually knew when they spoke. The complaint does not plead sufficiently particularized facts showing these individuals’ contemporaneous knowledge of falsity when they made the challenged statements. Accordingly, the Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim is sustained as to RTX and Hayes, and dismissed as to the other Individual Defendants. Because the underlying Section 10(b) claim survives as to RTX and Hayes, the derivative Section 20(a) claim is sustained as to Hayes only and dismissed as to the remaining Individual Defendants.

claim_rulings.claim: Count I — Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5 (against RTX, Hayes, Mitchill, O’Brien, Calio, Eddy)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis:
PSLRA requires particularized facts giving rise to a strong inference of scienter as to each defendant.

1) Particularized allegations of knowledge of falsity when statements were made:
• RTX / Hayes: The complaint pleads particularized facts that, by 2020, the company identified contamination in powdered metal after the March 2020 V2500 disk incident and understood it created a ‘suspect population’ spanning late 2015–2020/early 2021. It further alleges extensive internal remediation (nine process changes through Q4 2021) and regulatory interactions/root-cause analyses. Critically, it pleads Hayes’s own later admissions (July 25, 2023 and Sept. 11, 2023 calls) that the issue was uncovered in 2020, that the company knew the suspect population existed, and that the manufacturing-process changes occurred in 2021. Taking those pleaded admissions as true at the motion-to-dismiss stage, they support an inference that Hayes knew (or was at least deliberately reckless in not knowing) that public statements during 2021–2023 describing GTF issues as ‘addressed,’ ‘behind us,’ or fully accounted for were misleading insofar as they omitted the known contamination population and the likelihood of large-scale removals/inspections.
• Mitchill / O’Brien / Calio / Eddy: The complaint identifies public statements by each, but does not plead comparably particularized facts showing what each actually knew at the time. The former-employee allegations describe internal awareness at engineering/operations levels and meetings (e.g., an August 2019 telcon; discussions in 2023 ‘coffee talks’; shifting cost estimates), but they are not tied with specificity to these speakers’ receipt of reports, attendance at identified meetings, contemporaneous emails, or other concrete channels of knowledge. Allegations that they were senior executives, that the GTF was a core operation, that they signed SEC filings, or that they ‘must have known’ are insufficient under the PSLRA.

2) Strong inference of scienter vs. innocent explanations:
• RTX / Hayes: The more compelling inference is at least recklessness (and plausibly intent) as to the omission/mischaracterization of a known manufacturing escape affecting a multi-year population of engines. Hayes’s alleged admissions that the issue was uncovered in 2020, that a suspect population existed, and that remediation took 18 months, when juxtaposed with repeated public assurances during the Class Period that issues were ‘addressed,’ ‘behind us,’ and fully contemplated in guidance, supports a strong inference that Hayes acted with scienter. Innocent explanations (e.g., evolving engineering understanding, uncertainty about scope, reliance on models) are less compelling at this stage because the pleading alleges contemporaneous knowledge of the suspect population timeframe and the need for significant process changes, plus subsequent disclosures describing the issue as requiring accelerated removals and multi-billion dollar impacts.
• Mitchill / O’Brien / Calio / Eddy: As to these individuals, the inference of nonfraudulent conduct (optimistic but incomplete public messaging; reliance on subordinates; evolving understanding of scope/timing; compartmentalized knowledge) is at least as plausible as fraudulent intent because the complaint does not plead particularized contemporaneous knowledge of falsity. Under Tellabs and the PSLRA, that is insufficient to plead a strong inference of scienter as to each of them.

Disposition: The claim is sustained as to RTX and Hayes only, and dismissed as to Mitchill, O’Brien, Calio, and Eddy for failure to plead scienter with the required particularity.

claim_rulings.claim: Count II — Section 20(a) control person liability (against Hayes, O’Brien, Mitchill, Calio, Eddy)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis:
Section 20(a) is derivative and requires a primary violation. Because Count I survives as to RTX and Hayes, a derivative control-person claim may proceed against a defendant adequately alleged to have controlled RTX and to have been a culpable participant.

• Hayes: The complaint plausibly alleges control (CEO/Chairman; signing filings; speaking on calls) and, for the reasons stated in Count I, sufficiently pleads culpable participation.
• O’Brien / Mitchill / Calio / Eddy: Because Count I is dismissed as to these individuals for failure to plead scienter, and the complaint does not otherwise plead culpable participation with particularity, the Section 20(a) claim is dismissed as to them.

Disposition: Sustained as to Hayes; dismissed as to O’Brien, Mitchill, Calio, and Eddy.

response.summary: Applying the PSLRA’s heightened pleading standards, the complaint does not plead with particularity facts giving rise to a strong inference that any defendant knew the challenged statements were false when made, or acted with deliberate recklessness. The core theory is that Danaher’s bioprocessing guidance and commentary proved overly optimistic and was repeatedly revised downward as market conditions evolved (COVID roll-off, customer destocking, biotech funding constraints, China weakness). That is not enough. Most allegations amount to fraud by hindsight and generalized assertions that defendants ‘must have known’ because bioprocessing was important, because Danaher had forecasting processes, and because analysts asked questions. The only arguably particularized scienter allegation—CW4’s claim that Blair ‘made up’ projections with IR—is not pleaded with sufficient detail and reliability to support a strong inference of intent to defraud, and in any event does not tie specific contemporaneous internal data to specific challenged public statements and explain why those statements were false at the time. Insider sales allegations are not pleaded as unusual or suspicious in a way that meaningfully strengthens scienter. Because the Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim is dismissed, the derivative Section 20(a) claim is also dismissed.

claim_rulings.claim: Count I — Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5 (against all defendants)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis:
1) Particularized knowledge of falsity: Not adequately pleaded. The complaint pleads that defendants issued optimistic forecasts and reassurances about bioprocessing demand, inventory/destocking, and COVID-related revenues, then later reduced guidance as conditions worsened. But it does not plead specific contemporaneous facts showing that, at the time of each statement, Blair, McGrew, or Ligner actually knew the statements were false. Allegations about Danaher’s general forecasting ‘rollup’ process, ‘customer intimacy,’ surveys, and the importance of bioprocessing are generalized corporate-knowledge allegations, not particularized facts of what each individual defendant learned, when, from whom, and how that information contradicted the public statements. The complaint also does not identify specific internal reports/metrics (e.g., customer-level order cancellations, inventory levels, backlog quality, China order trend, monthly FC forecasts for bioprocessing) presented to the individual defendants on specific dates that rendered the challenged guidance unattainable when issued.

The CW allegations largely do not bridge this gap. CW1 describes helping Blair prepare for town halls and reviewing operating results/metrics, but does not identify what metrics showed, when they showed it, and how they contradicted specific public claims. CW2 and CW3 concern forecasting mechanics in EAS/water-quality businesses, not bioprocessing, and do not supply defendant-specific knowledge about Cytiva/Pall orders or inventory. CW4’s allegation that Blair ‘yelled’ on a post–Q1 2022 call and said he and IR ‘made up’ better projections is conclusory and lacks the necessary particulars (date/time, who was present, what projections were changed, what the original subsidiary projections were, what the ‘made up’ figures were, and how they mapped onto specific public guidance). It also does not plead that McGrew or Ligner participated in or knew of that alleged conduct. Without those particulars, CW4 does not support a strong inference that any specific public statement was knowingly false when made.

2) Strong inference vs. innocent explanations: The more compelling inference from the pleaded facts is nonfraudulent—management made forward-looking judgments in a volatile post-pandemic demand environment, initially underestimated the magnitude/duration of destocking and funding headwinds, and updated guidance as visibility improved. The complaint’s narrative tracks a common pattern of forecast revisions in changing markets; that is at least as plausible as intentional deception. Assertions that defendants ‘denied’ stockpiling or overstated resilience are not enough absent particularized contemporaneous contradictory facts known to defendants. The insider trading allegations do not materially change the calculus: the complaint does not plead the context necessary to show the sales were unusual (e.g., 10b5-1 plan details, trading history, total holdings over time, percentage of compensation, or whether sales were pre-scheduled/consistent). The ‘core operations’ theory (bioprocessing’s importance) and analyst questioning are insufficient under the PSLRA to establish scienter without specific contradictory internal information.

Accordingly, the complaint fails to plead scienter with the required particularity and fails to allege facts giving rise to a strong inference of intent or deliberate recklessness.

claim_rulings.claim: Count II — Section 20(a) control person liability (against Blair and McGrew)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Section 20(a) is derivative. Because Count I (the alleged primary violation under Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5) is dismissed for failure to plead scienter under the PSLRA, the Section 20(a) claim necessarily fails and is dismissed.

response.summary: Applying the PSLRA’s heightened pleading standards, the complaint pleads (at most) a conflicted M&A process and allegedly misleading proxy disclosures, but it does not plead with particularity facts giving rise to a strong inference that any defendant actually knew, at the time of the challenged statements, that those statements were false, or acted with the requisite intent to deceive (or severe recklessness) for Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5. The scienter allegations rely heavily on motives (fees, TRA payments, rollover interests), generalized “must have known” assertions tied to defendants’ roles, and hindsight disagreement with deal process and price. Those allegations support possible negligence or fiduciary-breach theories, but they do not satisfy the PSLRA’s strong-inference requirement for fraud. The Section 14(a) claim is pleaded as negligence and is not subject to the PSLRA scienter requirement in the same way; on the face of the complaint, plaintiffs plausibly allege material omissions/misstatements in the proxy concerning conflicts and the sale process sufficient to proceed at the pleading stage. Because the Section 10(b) claim is dismissed, any Section 20(a) claim predicated on that violation is dismissed; however, Section 20(a) may still proceed to the extent it is predicated on the surviving Section 14(a) claim.

claim_rulings.claim: Count I – Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5(a)-(c) (scheme/misstatement) against all defendants
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis:
1) Particularized knowledge-of-falsity: Not adequately pleaded. The complaint identifies allegedly false statements (e.g., Special Committee “independent and disinterested,” “robust process,” “best value reasonably obtainable,” and related proxy/process descriptions), and it alleges internal minutes/documents showing conflicts and process dynamics. But it does not plead particularized facts showing that any specific defendant, at the time of each challenged statement, actually knew the statement was false as opposed to disputably incomplete, opinion-based, or the product of a contested characterization of independence/process. The pleading repeatedly substitutes role-based assertions (“implausible they were unaware,” “privy to confidential information,” “had access,” “must have known”) for individualized facts tying each defendant to contemporaneous awareness of falsity for each statement.

2) Strong inference of scienter: Not met. Plaintiffs’ principal scienter theory is motive/opportunity: TRA payments, equity rollover interests, retention of management, Special Committee fee increases, and bankers’ contingent fees. Under the PSLRA, motive and opportunity—without particularized allegations of contemporaneous knowledge or deliberate concealment—generally do not create a strong inference of intent to deceive. The more compelling inference from the pleaded facts is that defendants had conflicts and incentives in a take-private process and made arguable disclosure errors or optimistic/advocacy characterizations typical of M&A solicitations, which supports negligence or fiduciary-breach-type wrongdoing rather than fraudulent intent. The complaint also risks “fraud by hindsight” by inferring scienter from the existence of a higher purported bid and a later-issued supplemental proxy, without pleading specific facts that defendants subjectively believed their earlier disclosures were false when made.

claim_rulings.claim: Count II – Section 14(a) and Rule 14a-9 (proxy misstatements/omissions) against Focus, Special Committee Defendants, Board Defendants, and Officer Defendants
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Scienter is not an element of a Section 14(a) claim as pleaded here (plaintiffs expressly plead negligence and disclaim fraud as to this count). At the pleading stage, the complaint plausibly alleges materially misleading proxy statements/omissions regarding: (i) Special Committee members’ conflicts and compensation changes proximate to approval; (ii) certain relationships and potential conflicts; (iii) banker conflicts and fee changes; and (iv) aspects of the sale process and competing-bid dynamics. Plaintiffs also plead transaction causation by alleging the proxy was an essential link to the shareholder vote. This ruling is without prejudice to later challenges on materiality, causation, or loss causation on a fuller record.

claim_rulings.claim: Count III – Section 20(a) control person liability against Special Committee Defendants, Board Defendants, and Officer Defendants
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Section 20(a) is derivative. Because the Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim is dismissed for failure to plead scienter, Section 20(a) is dismissed to the extent it is predicated on Count I. However, Count II (Section 14(a)) survives; accordingly, Count III may proceed only insofar as it is predicated on the surviving Section 14(a)/Rule 14a-9 theory and plaintiffs can ultimately establish a primary violation and control.

response.summary: Applying the PSLRA’s heightened pleading standards, the Court finds that the Complaint pleads (at most) that Walmart was subject to significant regulatory risk and that DOJ/DEA activity existed, but it does not plead with the required particularity facts giving rise to a strong inference that the Individual Defendants (McMillon and Biggs) actually knew the challenged SEC statements/omissions were false when made or acted with deliberate recklessness as to their falsity. The scienter allegations rely heavily on (i) corporate-level documents and generalized assertions about what senior executives ‘must have known,’ (ii) later-filed DOJ allegations and later MDL findings (classic hindsight), and (iii) membership on a compliance committee and signing SOX certifications (insufficient without particularized contemporaneous facts tying each defendant to knowledge of the specific disclosure falsity at the time). While the Complaint plausibly alleges that Walmart faced serious CSA compliance issues and government scrutiny, the more compelling competing inference is non-fraudulent: Walmart made debatable disclosure judgments about whether and how to describe investigations and contingent liabilities, including through generic ‘government investigations’ language, rather than intentionally deceiving investors. Because scienter is not adequately pleaded, the Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim is dismissed, and the derivative Section 20(a) claim is also dismissed.

claim_rulings.claim: Count I – Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5 (against Walmart, McMillon, and Biggs)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: 1) Particularized knowledge of falsity when made: Not adequately pleaded as to McMillon or Biggs. The Complaint identifies extensive alleged CSA noncompliance and government activity, but it does not plead specific contemporaneous facts showing that either Individual Defendant actually knew, at the time of the challenged SEC filings/press statements, that the particular statements were false or misleading. Allegations that McMillon ‘approved’ or was ‘consulted’ on DOJ presentations, that both sat on an Ethics/Compliance committee, that the Board was ‘informed’ of SOM risks, or that it is ‘inconceivable’ they were unaware are generalized corporate-knowledge assertions and speculation, not particularized facts. The cited internal materials (e.g., risk worksheets, proposals, compliance emails) are not pleaded with detail showing they were received/read by Biggs or McMillon at relevant times, nor do they tie either defendant to a decision to omit disclosure of the EDTX criminal/civil investigations from specific filings. 2) Strong inference of scienter: The pleaded facts do not create a strong inference that is at least as compelling as innocent explanations. A plausible non-fraudulent inference is that defendants made (even if ultimately wrong) materiality and disclosure-scope judgments about contingent liabilities and ‘contemplated proceedings,’ including using generic disclosure about subpoenas/investigations and risk factors, while disputing DOJ’s theories and attempting to avoid indictment. The Complaint’s reliance on later DOJ allegations (filed Dec. 2020) and later MDL outcomes (2021–2022) to infer earlier scienter is largely fraud-by-hindsight. Motive allegations (desire to avoid reputational harm, preserve sales, avoid penalties) are generic and do not substitute for particularized facts of intent. SOX certifications and executive roles, without more, do not satisfy the PSLRA. Accordingly, scienter is not pleaded with the required particularity, and Count I is dismissed.

claim_rulings.claim: Count II – Section 20(a) control person liability (against McMillon and Biggs)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Section 20(a) is derivative and requires a primary violation. Because the Court dismisses the Section 10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim for failure to plead scienter under the PSLRA, the Section 20(a) claim must also be dismissed.

response.summary: Applying the PSLRA’s heightened pleading standards, the Exchange Act §10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim is dismissed because the complaint does not plead with particularity facts showing any identified defendant’s contemporaneous knowledge of falsity (or severe recklessness) when the challenged statements were made, and thus does not give rise to a strong inference of scienter as required by Tellabs. The pleading largely relies on “upon information and belief,” “knew or should have known,” later nonperformance (withdrawal freeze), and generalized allegations of a fraudulent scheme—insufficient under the PSLRA and impermissibly close to fraud by hindsight. The remaining non-Exchange-Act causes of action are not subject to the PSLRA scienter pleading requirement; on this motion-to-dismiss record and based solely on the provided complaint text, they are adequately alleged at a notice-pleading level (subject to any other defenses not addressed here, such as arbitration, extraterritoriality, preemption, or Rule 9(b) as to state-law fraud). No §20(a) claim is pleaded in the provided complaint; if it were, it would be dismissed as derivative of the dismissed §10(b) claim.

claim_rulings.claim: Count I – Securities Act §§ 5 and 12(a)(1) (Unregistered offer/sale) (against CFT and FxWinning)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Not a §10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim; scienter is not an element of §12(a)(1).

claim_rulings.claim: Count II – Exchange Act §10(b) and Rule 10b-5 (against CFT, FxWinning, de Rocha, Cardenas, Brito Cutie)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis:
1) Particularized knowledge-of-falsity: Not adequately pleaded. The complaint identifies various promotional statements (high returns, proprietary algorithm/software, segregation/insurance/security, regulation, KPMG audit, withdrawal rights, KYC/AML explanations), but it does not plead specific, contemporaneous facts showing that any particular defendant actually knew those statements were false when made. Instead, it relies on (i) later events (withdrawals halted in 2023; funds not returned), (ii) conclusory formulations (“knowingly false or should have known,” “upon information and belief,” “easily verifiable through due diligence”), (iii) generalized assertions that “no trading occurred” or the “audit was fake” without the who/what/when/how of defendants’ awareness at the time, and (iv) broad allegations of personal benefit/commissions and later asset purchases without tying those facts to contemporaneous knowledge of falsity of specific statements.

2) Strong inference of scienter: Not met under Tellabs. The more compelling (or at least equally plausible) non-fraudulent inferences from the pleaded facts include operational failure, liquidity/provider issues, regulatory/KYC disruptions, mismanagement, or breach of contractual withdrawal obligations—none of which requires an inference that defendants, at the time of solicitation statements, intended to deceive. The complaint’s theory that defendants “never intended” to permit withdrawals is asserted conclusorily and inferred primarily from subsequent nonpayment, which is classic fraud-by-hindsight. Allegations of motive (fees/commissions) are generic and common to any business; absent particularized facts of contemporaneous falsity, they do not create a strong inference of scienter. Accordingly, the §10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim is dismissed.

claim_rulings.claim: Section 20(a) control person liability (if asserted)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Derivative of the underlying §10(b)/Rule 10b-5 violation. Because Count II is dismissed, any §20(a) claim necessarily fails and is dismissed.

claim_rulings.claim: Count III – Commodity Exchange Act §§ 6b, 6e, 6o, 25 (against CFT, FxWinning, de Rocha, Cardenas, Brito Cutie)
claim_rulings.scienter_analysis: Not a §10(b)/Rule 10b-5 claim; PSLRA scienter analysis not applicable.
